q: What are some ways to ease a black eye?
a: You can gently hold an ice pack wrapped in a cloth to the area around your eye for 10 to 20 minutes at a time, take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen, and apply a warm (not hot) heat pack or cloth regularly during the day.

q: When should I see a GP for a black eye?
a: You should see a GP if a black eye does not go away within 3 weeks.

q: What should I do if I have a black eye and a headache that won't go away?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: When should I go to A&E for a black eye?
a: You should go to A&E if you can see blood in your eye, have an irregularly shaped pupil, lost consciousness after a head blow, have vision problems, or cannot move your eye.

q: What are some symptoms to look out for after getting a black eye?
a: You should be concerned if you have blurry vision, warmness or pus around your eye, high temperature, or taking blood-thinning medicine or have a bleeding disorder.

q: How long does it usually take for a black eye to get better?
a: A black eye should get better within 2 to 3 weeks.

q: Is it safe to put ice directly on the skin for a black eye?
a: No, you should not put ice directly on your skin for a black eye.

q: Can aspirin make the bruising from a black eye worse?
a: Yes, aspirin can make the bruising from a black eye worse, so it should not be taken unless prescribed by a doctor.

q: What should I do if I have double vision and a black eye?
a: You should go to A&E, as double vision along with a black eye can be a cause for concern.

q: What should I do if I see blood in my eye after getting a black eye?
a: You should go to A&E if you see blood in your eye after getting a black eye.

q: What can I do to ease a black eye?
a: You can gently hold an ice pack wrapped in a cloth to the area around your eye, take painkillers, and apply a warm (not hot) heat pack or cloth to the area. Avoid taking aspirin and do not press or rub the area.

q: When should I see a GP for a black eye?
a: You should see a GP if the black eye does not go away within 3 weeks.

q: What should I do if I have a black eye and a headache that doesn't go away?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: What should I do if the area around my eye is warm and leaking pus?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: What should I do if I can see blood in my eye?
a: You should go to A&E immediately.

q: What should I do if I had a blow to the head and lost consciousness or have been sick?
a: You should go to A&E immediately.

q: What should I do if I have problems with my vision after a blow to the head?
a: You should go to A&E immediately.

q: What should I do if I'm taking blood-thinning medicine and have a black eye?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: What should I do if I cannot move my eye after a blow to the head?
a: You should go to A&E immediately.

q: What should I do if I have a black eye and a high temperature or feel hot and shivery?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.
